choices.text: Adenylyl cyclase
Guanylyl cyclase
Phospholipase C

questions.text: Beta 2 receptor action leading to hyperglycemia/ hypoglycemia is mediated by which of the following enzymes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adenylyl cyclase

 

Explanation

 

Beta 2 receptor action leading to hypoglycemia/ hyperglycemia is mediated by adenylyl cyclase.

 

Catecholamines act through beta 2 receptors and they use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system to stimulate the target tissues.

 

Cyclic AMP is synthesized from ATP by the action of the enzyme adenylyl cyclase.

 

  • Binding of the hormone to its receptor activates a G protein which, in turn, activates adenylyl cyclase
  • The resulting rise in cAMP turns on the appropriate response in the cell by either (or both):
    • Changing the molecular activities in the cytosol, often using Protein Kinase A (PKA) — a cAMP-dependent protein kinase that phosphorylates target proteins
    • Turning on a new pattern of gene transcription

 

Cyclic AMP produces one or more of the following responses:

 

  1. Contraction and relaxation of muscle fibers
  2. Alteration in the permeability of cell membrane
  3. Synthesis of substances inside the cell
  4. Secretion or release of substances by target cell
  5. Other physiological activities of the target cell

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Guanylyl cyclase: Incorrect. While guanylyl cyclase also produces a cyclic nucleotide (cGMP) that acts as a second messenger, it is not involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor pathway.

 

Option C. Phospholipase C: Incorrect. Phospholipase C is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, not Gs-coupled receptors like the beta-2 receptors. It catalyzes the breakdown of phosphatidylinositol bisphosphate into diacylglycerol and inositol triphosphate, which are involved in calcium signaling.

 

Option D. Phospholipase A2: Incorrect. This enzyme liberates arachidonic acid from phospholipids, leading to the production of eicosanoids (like prostaglandins and leukotrienes). It is not directly involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor signaling pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other hormones that use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system are:

 

  • ACTH
  • Angiotensin II
  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone
  • Calcitonin
  • FSH
  • Glucagon
  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone
  • HCG
  • Luteinizing hormone
  • Parathyroid hormone
  • Secretin
  • Somatostatin
  • TSH
  • Vasopressin

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) West syndrome

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

 

  • West syndrome is a severe generalised epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:
    • Infantile spasm
    • Developmental regression
    • Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes.

 

Treatment of West syndrome includes:

 

  • ACTH
  • Vigabatrin when associated with tuberous sclerosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: Young adults who have juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) commonly experience myoclonic jerks in the morning. Valproate is helpful in treating benign myoclonic epilepsy, whereas levetiracetam is helpful in treating severe myoclonic epilepsies.

 

Option B. Rolandic epilepsy: Rolandic epilepsy is benign epilepsy seen in children. They present at night or while awakening.

 

Option D. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS): Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a rare but severe form of childhood epilepsy characterized by a triad of multiple seizure types, characteristic EEG findings, and intellectual impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

questions.text: Fibres of the given structure originate from? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

The given structure is the fornix and its fibres arise from the hippocampus.

 

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter fibers that connects the hippocampus to other regions of the brain, including the mammillary bodies, thalamus, and septal nuclei. The fibers of the fornix arise from the hippocampus, which is involved in the formation and consolidation of memories, and then project through the fornix to other parts of the limbic system. Dysfunction of the fornix and hippocampus can result in memory impairments, as seen in conditions such as Alzheimer's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amygdala: The amygdala is a small almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes of the brain. It is involved in processing emotions, especially fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala does have connections to the limbic system, it is not a direct source of fibers for the fornix. However, it does interact with the hippocampus and other limbic structures.

 

Option B. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain, specifically in the diencephalon. They are closely connected to the hippocampus and are considered part of the limbic system. The fornix sends fibers to and receives fibers from the mammillary bodies, facilitating the flow of information within the limbic circuit.

 

Option C. Caudate Nucleus: The caudate nucleus is a component of the basal ganglia and is involved in motor control and cognitive functions. While it interacts with some limbic structures, it is not a primary source of fornix fibers. Instead, it has connections with other regions involved in motor control and reward processing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hippocampus is a critical structure within the limbic system that plays a central role in memory formation and spatial navigation. It is the primary source of fibers that make up the fornix. The fornix carries information from the hippocampus to other limbic structures, including the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nuclei, as well as to the septal nuclei and the cingulate gyrus.

choices.text: B and C
A and B
A, B, C

questions.text:
Which of the following drug reduces mortality in COVID-19 patients? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Dexamethasone

B. Remdesivir

C. Favipiravir
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only A

 

  • In severe COVID-19 infection, there is a systemic inflammatory response, which can lead to lung injury and multiple organ dysfunction. Corticosteroids, due to their anti-inflammatory effect, can help mitigate these negative effects and reduce the mortality in patients.
  • Only dexamethasone has been shown to reduce mortality in severe covid19 cases.
  • Dexamethasone 6 mg IV/PO once daily for 10 days or until hospital discharge is given in severe cases. In the absence of dexamethasone, equivalent doses of other corticosteroids such as prednisone, methylprednisone, or hydrocortisone may be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Remdesivir

 

  • Mechanism: Remdesivir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used to reduce the duration of illness in COVID-19 patients, but it has not been conclusively shown to reduce mortality.

 

Option C. Favipiravir

 

  • Mechanism: Favipiravir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used in some countries for the treatment of COVID-19, but there is no strong evidence to support a reduction in mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is the only drug among the listed options that has been shown to reduce mortality in severe COVID-19 cases, due to its potent anti-inflammatory effects. Remdesivir and favipiravir have not demonstrated a mortality benefit.

questions.text: After a fall from a height, a 10-year-old child presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. Upon examination, the child's vital signs were stable, but tenderness was noted in the left lumbar region. What would be the best investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contrast enhanced CT scan

 

  • The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a fall is suggestive of blunt renal trauma.
  • Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross hematuria, shock in combination with microscopic hematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.
  • A CECT is the investigation of choice for blunt renal trauma in a hemodynamically stable patient.
  • Contrast enhanced CT scan (CECT):  Correct. In cases of trauma, especially from a fall, a CECT scan provides detailed imaging of the abdomen, allowing the visualization of internal organs, blood vessels, and tissues. When there's a suspicion of renal trauma due to tenderness in the left lumbar region (location of the kidney), CECT can identify the presence and extent of the injury. In a hemodynamically stable patient (as indicated by the child's stable vital signs), CECT is the preferred diagnostic modality for blunt renal trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retrograde urethrogram: This is a radiographic study of the posterior urethra using a contrast agent. It's primarily used when there's a suspicion of urethral injury, typically indicated by symptoms like blood at the urethral meatus or an inability to urinate.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach implies observation without immediate intervention or imaging. While "wait and watch" can be appropriate in some cases, the potential seriousness of blunt renal trauma (especially in a child) warrants a more proactive approach to accurately diagnose and manage the injury.

 

Option D. Emergency laparotomy: It's indicated in situations where there's significant internal injury, and immediate surgical intervention is required. While it's a possibility in cases of trauma, the child's stable vital signs suggest a more conservative diagnostic approach, like a CECT scan, should be performed first to determine the extent of injury before jumping to surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.

choices.text: Can occur in association with diabetes
Associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon
The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal
Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding scleredema?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Associated with sclerodactyly or Raynaud’s phenomenon.

 

Sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s Phenomenon are associated with Scleroderma (NOT with scleredema).

 

Scleredema & Scleroderma are different diseases.

 

 

Scleredema is not associated with sclerodactyly, Raynaud’s phenomenon, nail fold capillary changes or serum autoantibodies.

 

Scleredema:

Synonyms - Scleredema adultorum of Buschke, Scleredema Diabeticorum.

 

  • Scleredema results in taut skin with noticeable symmetrical, diffuse progressive, non-pitting induration. This is because the dermis has expanded, mucin has been deposited, and the subcutaneous fat has been replaced by coarse collagen fibers.
  • It commonly presents with erythema and induration on the posterior neck and back, along with a peau d'orange appearance of the skin. Interestingly, the hands and feet remain unaffected.
  • The condition is characterized by a 3-4 times thicker dermis than usual, caused by dysfunctional fibroblasts leading to increased type 1 collagen synthesis, but without fibroblast proliferation.

 

The most prevalent type of this condition is associated with diabetes mellitus, and it is more commonly found in men compared to other forms that are more frequently seen in women. The accumulation of collagen is attributed to irreversible glycosylation of collagen and its resistance to degradation by collagenase.

 

 

  • Against an erythematous backdrop, the image depicts scleredema in a diabetic patient with firm, non-pitting edema with induration on the upper back, neck, and shoulders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Can occur in association with diabetes: True, as scleredema is commonly associated with diabetes, where the glycosylation of collagen contributes to the pathology.

 

Option C. The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal: True, reflecting the histological changes in scleredema, including mucin deposition and increased type 1 collagen synthesis.

 

Option D. Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen: True, these are characteristic cutaneous manifestations of scleredema, indicating the skin's texture and appearance changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Bolognia 4th edition, chapter 46, page no 870

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 59 page no 59.09 - 59.11.

Question Level – HARD

Question Id-7440 Unique Key-Q1728345

questions.text: Which of the following International Health agencies is aiding in building toilets in India? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) FORD Foundation

 

Explanation:

 

The Ford Foundation has been active in India for several decades, supporting various initiatives aimed at alleviating poverty and promoting social justice. While the foundation's primary focus areas include public administration, urban planning, food security, women's empowerment, and inclusive education, it has also supported community-led initiatives that contribute to improved sanitation and public health. For instance, the foundation has partnered with local organizations to enhance living conditions in rural areas, which encompasses efforts to improve sanitation facilities

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red Cross: The Red Cross primarily focuses on disaster relief, emergency assistance, and health services but is not specifically known for aiding in the construction of toilets in India.

 

Option C. CARE: CARE has supported the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program in India but is not known for its involvement in building toilets.

 

Option D. USAID: The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) has been involved in various development projects in India, including health and sanitation initiatives. However, in the context of direct involvement in building toilets, the Ford Foundation's contributions are more prominently documented.

 

Educational Objective:

 

International Organization supporting specific programs - 

 

  • SIDA – TB
  • DANIDA – Blindness 
  • UNICEF – GOBI FFF campaign, applied nutrition program 
  • USAID – Technical Cooperation mission; supported SBM (Swatch Bharat Mission)
  • Rockefeller foundation – hookworm problem control & elimination; borehole latrines and establishment of AIIHPH (All India Institute of Hygiene and Public Health)
  • Colombo plan – Establishment of cobalt therapy unit (with the help of Canada) and AIIMS, New Delhi was established with financial assistant from New Zealand
  • FORD foundation – supporting sanitation initiatives in India, including the construction of toilets, to improve public health and living conditions. Also helped in establishment of NIHFW (National Institute of Health and Family Welfare) and RHTC (Rural Health and Training Centres)
  • CARE Foundation – Supported ICDS Program

questions.text: Identify the level of amputation: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Below Knee

 

The correct answer is Below Knee amputation. In the provided image, the amputation level shows both the tibia and fibula bones, indicating that the amputation is below the knee. A below knee amputation preserves the knee joint, which is crucial for improved mobility and prosthetic fitting compared to an above knee amputation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Above Knee: In an above knee amputation, only the femur would be visible as the amputation occurs above the knee joint, which is not the case in the image provided.

 

Option C. Lis Franc: A Lis Franc amputation is a type of foot amputation that involves the tarsometatarsal joints.

 

Option D. Chopart: A Chopart amputation involves a disarticulation through the midfoot, specifically at the talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints. The image does not show the foot structures required for a Chopart amputation, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a below knee amputation, both the tibia and fibula bones are visible, distinguishing it from above knee and foot-level amputations like Lis Franc and Chopart.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the OPD with bilateral swelling of lower limbs. On examination, there is elevated JVP, hepatomegaly, and ascites. What is your provisional diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac failure

 

The patient presents with symptoms and signs that are consistent with cardiac failure (congestive heart failure):

 

  • Bilateral swelling of lower limbs: Suggestive of peripheral edema, common in heart failure.
  • Elevated JVP (Jugular Venous Pressure): Indicates increased central venous pressure, often seen in right-sided heart failure.
  • Hepatomegaly: Enlargement of the liver due to congestion, often a sign of right-sided heart failure.
  • Ascites: Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity, which can occur in both cardiac and hepatic failure but is more indicative of cardiac failure in the absence of jaundice or other liver failure signs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Renal failure: Can cause peripheral edema but does not typically present with elevated JVP, hepatomegaly, and ascites in this manner.

 

Option C. Brain injury: Does not present with these systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Hepatic failure: While it can cause ascites and hepatomegaly, it would also present with jaundice and other liver-related symptoms, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac failure (congestive heart failure) often presents with elevated JVP, peripheral edema, hepatomegaly, and ascites, distinguishing it from other conditions like hepatic or renal failure.

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mid-abduction

 

IMPINGEMENT SYNDROME

 

  • It is soft tissues entrapment.
  • Tendinitis of the rotator cuff is the major cause of a painful shoulder.
  • The rotator cuff consists of the tendons of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, subscapularis, and teres minor muscles, and inserts on the humeral tuberosity.
  • The supraspinatus tendon is the most often affected, probably because of its repeated impingement between the humeral head and the undersurface of the anterior third of the acromion and coracoacromial ligament above as well as the reduction in its blood supply that occurs with abduction of the arm. This phenomenon is described as impingement syndrome.
  • The process begins with edema and hemorrhage of the rotator cuff which evolves to fibrotic thickening and eventually to rotator cuff degeneration with tendon tears and bone spurs.
  • Subacromial bursitis also accompanies this syndrome.
  • Symptoms usually appear after injury or overuse, especially with activities involving elevation of the arm with some degree of forward flexion.
  • Impingement syndrome occurs in persons participating in baseball, tennis, swimming, or occupations that require repeated elevation of the arm.
  • Severe pain is experienced when the arm is actively abducted into an overhead position. The arc between 60° and 120° (mid-range abduction) is especially painful. This is also described as “painful arc syndrome”.
  • NSAIDs, local glucocorticoid injection, and physical therapy may relieve symptoms.
  • Surgical decompression of the subacromial space may be necessary in patient refractory to conservative treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initial abduction: Incorrect, as the pain typically does not start at the beginning of abduction but becomes noticeable as the arm reaches mid-range.

 

Option C. Full range of abduction: Incorrect, although the entire range might be uncomfortable, the specific "painful arc" is usually observed in the mid-range.

 

Option D. Overhead abduction: Incorrect, as the term "painful arc syndrome" specifically refers to pain experienced in the mid-range of abduction, not necessarily when the arm is fully overhead.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful arc syndrome, a clinical manifestation of impingement syndrome, is observed during mid-range shoulder abduction, typically between 60° and 120°. This condition is often seen in individuals engaging in activities that involve repeated arm elevation, and management may include NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, or, in refractory cases, surgical intervention to decompress the subacromial space.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain since 4 days with a history of remitting fever and bradycardia after having meals outside frequently. Which test can be done in the patient to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood culture

 

The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, remitting fever, bradycardia, and a history of eating meals outside suggest a diagnosis of typhoidal salmonella. In the early phase of this infection, particularly within the first week, the most appropriate diagnostic test is a blood culture. Blood cultures are most effective in detecting Salmonella bacteria during the initial week of illness, which aligns with the patient's 4-day history of symptoms. Early detection through blood culture is crucial for initiating appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test: This test is typically performed in the second week of illness when antibodies against Salmonella begin to rise. Since the patient is only 4 days into the illness, the Widal test is not the most reliable at this stage.

 

Option C. Urine culture: Urine cultures may become positive later in the course of typhoid fever, typically in the third or fourth week. It is not useful in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option D. Stool culture: Stool cultures are generally useful in the later stages of typhoid fever, around the third week. They are not as effective for early detection within the first week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected cases of typhoidal salmonella presenting within the first week of symptoms, a blood culture is the most appropriate diagnostic test.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with complaints of dryness in the mouth and eyes. She also has dysphagia. On examination, dental caries and enlarged cervical lymph nodes are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sjogren syndrome

 

The patient's symptoms and clinical findings are characteristic of Sjogren syndrome:

 

  • Dryness in the mouth and eyes (xerostomia and keratoconjunctivitis sicca): These are hallmark features of Sjogren syndrome, caused by lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of the salivary and lacrimal glands.
  • Dysphagia: This can occur due to reduced saliva production, making swallowing difficult.
  • Dental caries: Poor saliva production leads to an increased risk of dental caries because saliva helps protect against tooth decay.
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes: Lymphadenopathy can be associated with Sjogren syndrome due to chronic inflammation.

 

Sjogren syndrome is an autoimmune disease primarily affecting the exocrine glands, leading to dry mouth and eyes, among other systemic manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed connective tissue disorders: These involve features of several autoimmune diseases (such as lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis) but do not typically present with the classic symptoms of dry mouth and eyes.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This can cause dry eyes and mouth but is more commonly associated with lung involvement and other systemic symptoms.

 

Option C. Wegener's granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis): This condition involves vasculitis and can affect the respiratory tract and kidneys, but it does not typically present with the primary symptoms of dry mouth and eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sjogren syndrome is characterized by dry mouth, dry eyes, dysphagia, dental caries, and lymphadenopathy, due to autoimmune destruction of exocrine glands.

questions.text:
Mrs. Smith has been referred to the plastic surgery department for the reconstruction of a large wound on her thigh. After a thorough examination, the surgeon decides to perform a skin graft. While discussing the procedure with Mrs. Smith, the surgeon explains the difference between split skin and full-thickness skin grafts. Identify the true statement regarding split thickness and full-thickness skin grafts:(INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Primary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  2. Secondary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  3. Primary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
  4. Secondary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Split skin grafts are partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a part of the dermis, while full-thickness grafts consist of the epidermis along with the entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. Primary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to passive recoil of the elastin fibers of the dermis in full thickness grafts. Since full-thickness grafts have more dermis (implying more elastin fibers), they undergo more primary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Secondary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to the pull of myofibroblasts, and it occurs over time, when the transplanted graft starts healing. Full-thickness grafts have more ability to resist the pull of myofibroblasts, hence they have less secondary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Primary contracture: FTSG

 

Secondary contracture: STSG

 

Thus, statements 2 and 3 are correct.

questions.text: Which of the following elicits maximum pain on injection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propofol

 

  • Propofol is notorious for causing pain upon injection.
  • The pain can be severe and is often described as a burning sensation.
  • Various techniques and adjuncts, like mixing with lidocaine or injecting into larger veins, have been recommended to minimize the pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketamine: While ketamine can sometimes cause a burning sensation upon injection, it's not typically described as the most painful among anesthetic agents. However, when not combined with other medications, it can cause some discomfort upon injection.

 

Option C. Etomidate: Etomidate can cause pain on injection, but the pain is generally less severe compared to propofol.

 

Option D. Thiopentone: Thiopentone can cause some pain upon injection, but it's generally less painful than propofol. However, it can cause tissue necrosis if it is inadvertently injected outside of the vein (extravasation).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is known to cause maximum pain on injection, often described as a severe burning sensation.

questions.text: In a patient in the ICU, an infection in the central venous catheter is noted. Staining showed a gram-positive oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida

 

Candida is a genus of yeast and is the most common cause of fungal infections in humans. It is characterized by its oval shape and its mode of reproduction through budding, a form of asexual reproduction. In a healthcare setting, particularly in the ICU, Candida infections are commonly associated with the use of central venous catheters. The yeast can colonize and infect these catheters, leading to systemic infections. The identification of a gram-positive, oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding points directly to Candida.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. E. coli: Escherichia coli is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium and does not reproduce by budding. It is typically associated with gastrointestinal infections, urinary tract infections, and other bacterial infections, but not with the description provided in this scenario.

 

Option C. Staph aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus in clusters and does not reproduce by budding. It is a common cause of various infections, including skin infections and catheter-associated infections, but its morphology and reproduction do not match the description of a budding organism.

 

Option D. Staph epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is also a gram-positive cocci and part of the normal skin flora. It is a common contaminant in blood cultures and can cause infections associated with indwelling medical devices, but it does not reproduce by budding and does not have an oval shape.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida is an oval-shaped yeast that reproduces by budding and is a common cause of catheter-associated infections in ICU patients.

choices.text: Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue
Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold
Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females

questions.text: True statement regarding the breast (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold

 

The axillary tail of Spence is an extension of the breast tissue that extends into the axilla (armpit area). It passes through the anterior axillary fold, which is a region near the front of the underarm. This anatomical feature is important for surgical considerations, particularly in breast surgeries and examinations for breast cancer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue: This statement is incorrect. The superior and medial quadrant of the breast does not have more tissue compared to other quadrants. The distribution of tissue in the breast is such that no specific quadrant is known to universally have more tissue in every individual.

 

Option B. 10 lobules are present: This statement is incorrect. The human breast typically contains around 15-20 lobules, not just 10. These lobules are responsible for the production of milk and are connected to ducts that lead to the nipple.

 

Option D. Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females: While the nipple is located at the level of the 4th intercostal space in males. In females, its position can vary among individuals due to the pendulous nature of the breast. Factors such as age, breast size, and body position can influence the exact location of the nipple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold, which is an important anatomical detail relevant in breast examinations and surgeries.

questions.text: In a patient with Horner syndrome, ptosis is most likely due to paralysis of which of the following muscles? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superior tarsal muscle

 

The superior tarsal muscle, also known as Muller's muscle, is a smooth muscle that assists in elevating the upper eyelid. In Horner syndrome, there is damage to the sympathetic nerve supply, specifically the T1 nerve, which innervates the superior tarsal muscle. Paralysis of this muscle leads to ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid, because the muscle cannot perform its function of aiding eyelid elevation. Horner syndrome typically results from a disruption in the sympathetic nerves, leading to symptoms like ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbitalis: This muscle provides support to the eyeball from the back. In Horner syndrome, although the orbitalis muscle may be affected, leading to a sunken appearance of the eyeball (apparent enophthalmos), it does not contribute directly to ptosis.

 

Option B. Levator superioris palpebrae: This muscle is primarily responsible for the elevation of the eyelid. However, it is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), not by the sympathetic nervous system, and its paralysis leads to significant ptosis, but this condition is unrelated to Horner syndrome.

 

Option C. Orbicularis Oculi: This muscle is responsible for closing the eyelid and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). Paralysis of this muscle leads to inability to close the eyelid but is not involved in ptosis due to Horner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Horner syndrome is characterized by ptosis due to paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle (Muller's muscle), which is innervated by sympathetic fibers, particularly from the T1 spinal nerve

questions.text: A child presents with cyanosis. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing a boot-shaped heart are suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease comprised of four components:

 

  1. Right ventricular hypertrophy –Boot shaped heart
  2. Ventricular septal defect – no heart failure
  3. Overriding of aorta
  4. Pulmonary stenosis (infundibulum)-Oligemia

 

If ASD plus – pentalogy of Fallot

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebstein's anomaly: Typically presents with an enlarged and downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which is not specifically indicated by the features in this X-ray.

 

Option B. Transposition of great arteries (TGA): Generally shows a characteristic "egg on a string" sign on chest X-ray, which is not evident in this image.

 

Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC): Would show features like a "snowman" or "figure of 8" heart due to dilatation of the supra-cardiac veins, which is not visible here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a distinctive boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray, correlating with the anatomical components of this congenital heart defect, making it a key diagnostic feature in cyanotic pediatric patients.

choices.text: Chest compression to Rescue breath ratio is 30:2

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding High-Quality CPR?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Depth of compression must be 3-4cm

 

The statement "Depth of compression must be 3-4cm" is incorrect for high-quality CPR. The correct depth of chest compression for adults is approximately 5 centimeters (or 2 inches). This depth ensures adequate blood flow during cardiopulmonary resuscitation. The 3-4cm depth mentioned in the option is insufficient for effective CPR in adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest compressions at 100-120/min: This is correct. The recommended rate for chest compressions during CPR is 100-120 compressions per minute. This rate optimizes blood flow during resuscitation efforts.

 

Option B. Allow adequate chest recoil: This statement is correct. Allowing full chest recoil between compressions is crucial for effective CPR. It enables proper diastolic filling of the heart, improving overall circulation.

 

Option C. Chest compression to Rescue breath ratio is 30:2: This is also correct. For adult CPR without an advanced airway, the standard ratio is 30 chest compressions followed by 2 rescue breaths.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In high-quality CPR for adults, the correct depth of chest compressions is approximately 5 centimeters (2 inches), not 3-4cm as stated in the incorrect option.

choices.text: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (pa02)

questions.text: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (pa02)

 

The increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2) is the main factor controlling the closure of the ductus arteriosus postnatally. Oxygen acts as a potent smooth muscle constrictor. When a newborn begins to breathe and cries, oxygen enters the lungs during inspiration, leading to an increase in paO2. This increased oxygen tension causes the smooth muscle in the ductus arteriosus to constrict, leading to its closure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in systemic vascular resistance: While systemic vascular resistance does increase after birth due to the cessation of placental circulation, it is not the primary factor responsible for ductal closure.

 

Option C. Increase in circulating prostaglandin levels: Prostaglandins, particularly PGE2, help keep the ductus arteriosus open. After birth, the levels of circulating prostaglandins decrease, contributing to ductal closure, but an increase in prostaglandins would not cause closure.

 

Option D. Decrease in pulmonary venous resistance: Pulmonary vascular resistance decreases after birth as the lungs expand and fill with air, allowing blood to flow more easily through the pulmonary circulation. However, this is not the direct cause of ductal closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2) postnatally is the most important factor for the closure of the ductus arteriosus.

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of these options is not a division originating from the external carotid artery within Kiesselbach's plexus? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: This artery is correctly identified as a branch of the maxillary artery, which itself is a major branch of the external carotid artery. It contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus by providing the septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Also a branch of the maxillary artery, the septal branch of the greater palatine artery participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: This artery, a branch of the facial artery (which originates from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARTERIAL SUPPLY OF THE NOSE:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Branches of ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System –

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

KIESSELBACH'S PLEXUS -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. She consumes a large amount of food, followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

 

The patient's behavior of consuming excessive amounts of food (binge eating) followed by self-induced vomiting (a purging behavior) is characteristic of Bulimia nervosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa typically involves restriction of food intake leading to significantly low body weight and a fear of gaining weight. Binge eating and purging can also occur in anorexia nervosa, and this question should have ideally provided more information; with the imited information provided, bulimia nervosa is a better answer as it is characterised by binging and purging.

 

Option C. Atypical depression is a subtype of major depression and is not characterized by binge eating and purging, although increased appetite is seen.

 

Option D. Binge eating disorder involves episodes of overeating but without the regular purging behaviors seen in Bulimia nervosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate behaviors such as self-induced vomiting (purging) or hypergymnasia to prevent weight gain. It is usually associated with fear of gaining weight. Purging can lead to dental caries, knuckle callouses, parotitis, hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis and rarely gastric or esophageal tear. Weight is usually normal, which differentiates from anorexia nervosa. Treatment includes CBT and SSRIs.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 469

questions.text: What is the duration of short-term memory? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30-300 seconds

 

Short-term memory lasts for seconds to minutes, hence of the given 4 options, 30-300 seconds is the most appropriate answer.

 

Common classification of memories that divides memories into

 

  1. Short-term memory, which includes memories that last for seconds or at most minutes unless they are converted into longer-term memories 
  2. Intermediate long-term memories, which last for days to weeks but then fade away
  3. Long-term memory, which, once stored, can be recalled up to years or even a lifetime later.

 

“working memory,” that includes mainly short-term memory that is used during the course of intellectual reasoning but is terminated as each stage of the problem is resolved.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Short-term memory lasts for seconds to minutes, storing information temporarily before it is either forgotten or encoded into long-term memory.

 

Additional Information 

 

Memories are frequently classified according to the type of information that is stored. 

 

1. Declarative memory basically means memory of the various details of an integrated thought, such as memory of an important experience that includes – 

  1. Memory of the surroundings, 
  2. Memory of time relationships, 
  3. Memory of causes of the experience, 
  4. Memory of the meaning of the experience, and 
  5. Memory of one’s deductions that were left in the person’s mind.
     

2. Skill memory is frequently associated with motor activities of the person’s body, such as all the skills developed for hitting a tennis ball, including automatic memories to 

  1. Sight the ball, 
  2. Calculate the relationship and speed of the ball to the racquet, and 
  3. Deduce rapidly the motions of the body, the arms, and the racquet required to hit the ball as desired.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amino acid-derived neurotransmitter? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatine

 

The question asks which of the listed options is not a neurotransmitter derived from amino acids. To answer this, let's break down each of the options:

 

  • Dopamine is a well-known neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine. Tyrosine is first converted to DOPA, which then converts to dopamine. Dopamine plays various roles in the brain, including involvement in reward, motivation, and the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.
  • Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine) is derived from the amino acid tryptophan. Tryptophan is converted into 5-hydroxytryptophan, which is then decarboxylated to form serotonin. Serotonin is involved in mood regulation, sleep, and other functions.
  • GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate. The conversion of glutamate to GABA involves a decarboxylation reaction that requires vitamin B6 as a cofactor. GABA plays a crucial role in reducing neuronal excitability throughout the nervous system.
  • Creatine, however, is not a neurotransmitter. While creatine is synthesized from the amino acids glycine, arginine, and methionine, it functions primarily as a molecule that helps to supply energy to cells, particularly muscle cells, by regenerating ATP (adenosine triphosphate). Creatine is not involved in neurotransmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine.

 

Option B. Serotonin: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tryptophan.

 

Option C. GABA: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatine is not a neurotransmitter. It is a molecule that plays a key role in energy metabolism, particularly in muscle cells, but it does not function in neurotransmission. Dopamine, serotonin, and GABA, on the other hand, are all neurotransmitters derived from amino acids.

choices.text: Scapular region and neck
Trunk and shoulder
Perineum and leg
Face and neck

questions.text: In the sagittal section of the brain given below the colored area. Which of the following structures are affected in a lesion to this area? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perineum and leg

 

The colored area in the sagittal section of the brain corresponds to the paracentral lobule, which is located on the medial surface of the brain. This region is responsible for the sensory and motor innervation of the perineum and leg areas.

 

Lesions in the paracentral lobule can lead to sensory and motor deficits in these regions. Bilateral involvement of this area can result in urinary incontinence due to loss of control over the muscles involved in bladder function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scapular region and neck: These areas are innervated by regions in the lateral aspect of the motor and sensory cortices, not the medial paracentral lobule.

 

Option B. Trunk and shoulder: Similar to option A, these regions are controlled by the lateral portions of the motor and sensory cortices.

 

Option D. Face and neck: These are controlled by the lower parts of the motor and sensory cortices located laterally, not medially in the paracentral lobule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The paracentral lobule provides sensory and motor innervation to the perineum and legs. Lesions in this area can affect these regions and potentially lead to urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A patient presented with ptosis which gets worsened by evening. He was diagnosed to be a case of myasthenia gravis. What is the preferred treatment of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyridostigmine

 

Pyridostigmine is the preferred initial treatment for myasthenia gravis. It is effective in improving muscle strength by inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine, thereby increasing its availability at the neuromuscular junction. Other options like plasma exchange and cyclosporine are typically reserved for more severe cases or when standard treatments fail. Physostigmine is not commonly used for myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasma Exchange: This is used in myasthenia gravis, particularly in cases of myasthenic crisis or before surgery. It's an acute treatment method rather than a long-term management strategy.

 

Option B. Cyclosporine: This is an immunosuppressant used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis, usually in cases where patients do not respond to first-line treatments or as an adjunct therapy.

 

Option D. Physostigmine: Unlike pyridostigmine, physostigmine is not commonly used for myasthenia gravis because of its central adverse effects. It is a lipid soluble cholinesterase inhibitor and is mainly used in atropine poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor and is the mainstay of treatment for myasthenia gravis. It helps increase the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby improving muscle strength.

choices.text: MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks
MTP can be done till 24 weeks
MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk
MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl, a victim of rape, presents at 22 weeks for abortion. What advice will you give her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B)  MTP can be done till 24 weeks

 

The MTP Act of 2021 in India allows for abortions b/w 20- 24 weeks in specific cases, including:

 

  • Rape or sexual assault: The girl in the question is a victim of rape, which falls under this category.
  • Risk to maternal life or Disability: If continuing the pregnancy poses a significant risk to the mother's health or life.
  • Substantial fetal anomaly: If the fetus has severe abnormalities incompatible with life or causing significant disability.
  • Minors: The girl is 14 years old, making her a minor, and the law provides special considerations for them.
  • Change in marital status or humanitarian grounds: These are additional situations where MTP may be considered up to 24 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks: This is incorrect. While the general limit for MTP is 20 weeks, certain circumstances, like rape, allow for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option C. MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk: This is partially correct. While risk to the mother's life is a valid reason, it's not the only one. Rape is also a valid indication for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option D. MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly: Again, this is partially correct. Substantial fetal anomaly is one reason, but rape is another valid reason for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, under the MTP Act of 2021:

questions.text: The green-shaded region in the coronal section of the brain corresponds to which type of fibers? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Projection

 

The internal capsule, a type of projection fibre, is the marked structure.

 

Projection fibres -

 

  • Connect the cerebral cortex to other brain areas and the spinal cord.
  • These fibers run vertically, either ascending to the cortex (afferent fibers bringing in sensory information) or descending from the cortex (efferent fibers sending out motor commands).
  • The corona radiata and the internal capsule are examples of areas containing many projection fibers.
  • They facilitate communication between the cortex and other parts of the CNS like the brainstem, thalamus, and spinal cord.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Short Association:

 

  • Also known as "U-fibers" or "short arcuate fibers" which connect neighboring gyrus.
  • They allow for communication between adjacent or nearby cortical regions.
  • Primarily found in the gray matter just below the cortical surface.
  • Their presence helps in localized processing and integration of information within a single cerebral hemisphere.

 

Option B. Long Association:

 

  • Connect more distant areas within the same hemisphere.
  • Examples include the superior longitudinal fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the posterior temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes, and the uncinate fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the anterior temporal lobe.
  • These fibers are crucial for integrating information across distant cortical areas within the same hemisphere.

 

Option D. Commissural:

 

  • Connect corresponding regions of the two cerebral hemispheres, allowing them to communicate with each other.
  • The most prominent example is the corpus callosum, which is the largest white matter structure in the brain and provides a broad band of neural connections between the left and right cerebral hemispheres. Other examples include the anterior commissure and the posterior commissure.
  • These fibers are essential for the two hemispheres to share information and coordinate activity.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Opinion of 1 doctor
Opinion of 2 doctors
Husband’s permission with 1 doctor
Permission of medical board

questions.text: A fetus diagnosed with neural tube defect at 21 weeks. The parents want an MTP at 21 weeks. What opinions are required? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Opinion of 2 doctors

 

Explanation:

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, which was amended in 2021, significant changes were made to the requirements for performing an MTP in India.

 

Under the old act, MTP was allowed up to 20 weeks, with the opinion of one registered medical practitioner (RMP) required up to 12 weeks, and the opinion of two RMPs required from 12 to 20 weeks.

 

The 2021 amendment extended the permissible period for MTP to 24 weeks. The new guidelines specify that:

 

  • Up to 20 weeks, the opinion of one RMP or gynecologist is required.
  • From 20 to 24 weeks, the opinion of two gynecologists is required.
  • For pregnancies beyond 24 weeks, MTP can be performed only if there is a substantial fetal anomaly, which must be determined by a medical board. This board typically consists of specialists such as a radiologist, a gynecologist, a pediatrician, and other relevant subspecialists based on the nature of the anomaly.

 

In this scenario, since the fetus is diagnosed with a neural tube defect at 21 weeks and the parents request an MTP, the opinion of two doctors is required.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Opinion of 1 doctor: This is required only up to 20 weeks of pregnancy, not beyond.

 

Option C. Husband’s permission with 1 doctor: The husband’s permission is not a requirement under the MTP Act.

 

Option D. Permission of medical board: This is required for performing MTP after 24 weeks if there is a substantial fetal anomaly.

 

Educational objective

 

For an MTP between 20 to 24 weeks of pregnancy, the opinion of two gynecologists is required as per the 2021 amendment to the MTP Act in India.

questions.text: A male patient had feeble femoral pulses with an upper-limb blood pressure of 186/90 mmHg. Chest X-ray showed enlarged intercostal arteries. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Coarctation of aorta

 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital condition characterized by the narrowing of the aorta, which causes an obstruction to blood flow. This condition leads to high blood pressure in the arteries that are proximal to the narrowing (upper limbs) and lower blood pressure in the arteries distal to the narrowing (lower limbs).

 

The key findings in this scenario include:

 

  • Feeble femoral pulses: Due to reduced blood flow past the coarctation.
  • Upper limb hypertension: Caused by increased resistance proximal to the coarctation.
  • Chest X-ray showing enlarged intercostal arteries: These develop as collateral circulation to bypass the coarctation, which can cause rib notching seen on X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD): An ASD is a hole in the septum between the heart's atria. It typically causes a left-to-right shunt and can lead to increased pulmonary blood flow and right heart overload. It does not cause differential blood pressure between limbs or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Option C. Bicuspid aortic valve: A bicuspid aortic valve is a congenital valve anomaly that can lead to aortic stenosis or regurgitation but does not typically cause differential blood pressure between the limbs or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Option D. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): A PDA is a persistent opening between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. It causes a continuous murmur and can lead to heart failure if significant but does not cause differential blood pressure or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta should be suspected in patients with a significant difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower limbs, feeble femoral pulses, and chest X-ray findings of enlarged intercostal arteries, indicating collateral circulation.

questions.text: Which structures pass between superior and middle constrictor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal Nerve)

 

The pharyngeal constrictor muscles are organized into three main parts: the superior, middle, and inferior constrictors. Each of these muscles plays a crucial role in the mechanics of swallowing and speech.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passes between the superior and middle constrictor muscles. This is a key anatomical relationship to remember as it is crucial for the nerve supply to the pharynx.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian Tube: Passes through the sinus of Morgagni, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option C. Superior Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the middle and inferior constrictors, not the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option D. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the inferior constrictor and the esophagus, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal nerve) and the stylopharyngeus muscle pass between the superior and middle constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

questions.text: The possible diagnosis for a child whose mother had a history of bronchial asthma & child developed itchy plaques bilaterally over the popliteal fossa, & cubital fossa (as shown below) could be? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atopic dermatitis

 

The image displays a child, with scratch marks and excoriations from itchy plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae, with a maternal history of bronchial asthma indicative of

 

Atopic dermatitis (or eczema).

 

  • This chronic inflammatory skin condition often occurs in families with atopy, encompassing asthma, hay fever, and allergic rhinitis.
  • The patient's personal history reveals a chronic and recurrent course of this condition.

 

In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.

 

  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  • Infantile
  • Childhood
  • Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas.
  • Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following 
    • Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any topic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications:

 

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

 

  • It is frequently observed in individuals in their 40s.
  • This is an intensely pruritic condition predominantly affecting extensor surfaces of the body, rather than the flexures and associated with gluten sensitivity and is characterized by grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. It is not related to a history of atopy.

 

Option C. Pemphigus vegetans:

 

  • A variant of pemphigus vulgaris, pemphigus vegetans presents with vegetating plaques, usually in the intertriginous areas.
  • It is not associated with a familial history of atopy and does not predominantly affect the popliteal and cubital fossae.

 

Option D. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, scaly plaques.
  • While psoriasis can affect any area of the body but more commonly extensor involvement is seen, it does not typically present as pruritic plaques in the popliteal

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with a familial history of atopy presenting with itchy plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae, Atopic Dermatitis is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19, volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Image source:

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Atopic_dermatitis

questions.text: Vaccine that requires strain change due to evolving organism is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Influenza

 

 

The influenza vaccine is unique among vaccines because it requires periodic updates or strain changes almost every year. This necessity is due to the evolving nature of the influenza virus, particularly the frequent antigenic changes in its surface glycoproteins (hemagglutinin and neuraminidase). These changes can occur through two primary mechanisms:

 

  • Antigenic Drift: Minor changes that occur gradually over time as the virus replicates. These small genetic mutations can alter the antigenic properties of the virus, necessitating updates to the vaccine to maintain its effectiveness.
  • Antigenic Shift: Less frequent but more significant changes that can lead to the emergence of a completely new influenza virus subtype. This can potentially lead to pandemics if the new subtype spreads widely and the population has little to no immunity against it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diphtheria: The vaccine for diphtheria does not require frequent updates or strain changes. The causative bacterium (Corynebacterium diphtheriae) does not exhibit the same level of antigenic variation that necessitates vaccine modification.

 

Option C. Polio: Polio vaccines target stable viral antigens of the poliovirus, which do not undergo frequent antigenic changes, thus not requiring periodic strain updates.

 

Option D. Typhoid: Typhoid vaccines, such as those for Salmonella Typhi, also do not require frequent changes in formulation, as the bacterial antigens are relatively stable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The influenza vaccine must be updated regularly to match the antigenically evolving influenza virus strains, primarily due to antigenic drift (gradual) and shift (drastic). This adaptation is essential to enhance vaccine effectiveness and control the spread of flu each season, highlighting the dynamic challenge of influenza virus surveillance and vaccine formulation.

questions.text: In a cohort study done in a community, out of those 100 vaccinated for malaria, only 6 developed the disease. At the same time, out of those 100 non-vaccinated, a total of 12 developed the disease. Find the relative risk in the study:  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.5

 

To find the relative risk (RR) in this study, we first need to calculate the incidence of the disease in both the vaccinated (exposed) and non-vaccinated (non-exposed) groups.

 

Step 1: Incidence in the vaccinated group (exposed):

 

  • Number of vaccinated individuals = 100
  • Number of vaccinated individuals who developed the disease = 6
  • Incidence in the vaccinated group = 6/100 = 0.06

 

Step 2: Incidence in the non-vaccinated group (non-exposed):

 

  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals = 100
  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals who developed the disease = 12
  • Incidence in the non-vaccinated group = 12/100 = 0.12

 

Step 3: Calculate Relative Risk (RR):
 

  • RR = Incidence in the exposed group / Incidence in the non-exposed group
  • RR = 0.06 / 0.12 = 0.5

 

The relative risk of 0.5 indicates that the vaccinated individuals were half as likely to develop malaria compared to those who were not vaccinated. This suggests a protective effect of the vaccine against malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a cohort study, the relative risk is calculated by comparing the incidence of the outcome in the exposed group to the incidence in the non-exposed group.

 

A relative risk less than 1 indicates a protective effect of the exposure, as seen in this example where vaccination reduced the risk of malaria.

questions.text: A person consumed 2 bottles of alcohol purchased from a local shop and presented to the emergency department with blurring of vision, nausea, confusion, and hypotension. What should be given for the treatment? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethyl alcohol

 

Explanation:

 

Blurring of vision, along with other symptoms such as nausea, confusion, and hypotension, suggests methyl alcohol (methanol) poisoning. Methyl alcohol is toxic because its metabolism produces formic acid, which is particularly harmful to the eyes and can cause blindness.

 

Key points to understand about methyl alcohol poisoning and its treatment:

 

  1. Methyl Alcohol (Methanol) Poisoning:
    • Methanol is often used to adulterate ethyl alcohol (ethanol) in locally produced alcoholic beverages because it is cheaper and has similar initial effects.
    • Methanol metabolism produces formic acid, which is toxic, particularly to the eyes, causing symptoms like blurring of vision.
  2. Treatment of Methanol Poisoning:
    • Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol): Ethanol is used as an antidote for methanol poisoning because it competes with methanol for alcohol dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for metabolizing both alcohols. By competing for this enzyme, ethanol prevents the formation of toxic metabolites from methanol.
    • Fomepizole (4-Methylpyrazole): Another antidote that inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase and prevents the formation of toxic metabolites.
    • Sodium Bicarbonate: Used to correct metabolic acidosis.
    • Dialysis: Used in severe cases to remove methanol and formic acid from the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flumazenil: Incorrect because flumazenil is the antidote for benzodiazepine poisoning.

 

Option C. Atropine: Incorrect as atropine is used for organophosphate and other cholinergic poisonings.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Incorrect because naloxone is the antidote for opioid poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blurring of vision, nausea, confusion, and hypotension in the context of alcohol consumption from a local shop strongly suggest methanol poisoning. The appropriate treatment is ethyl alcohol, which competes with methanol for metabolism and prevents the formation of toxic metabolites.

 

Table for Treatment of Methanol and Ethylene Glycol Poisoning

questions.text: Amsel criteria is used for? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis

 

Explanation:

 

Amsel's criteria are used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV). The diagnosis requires at least three out of the following four criteria to be present:

 

  1. Homogeneous, thin, white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls.
  2. Clue cells on microscopy: Vaginal epithelial cells that appear stippled with bacteria.
  3. Positive whiff test: A fishy odor is released when a solution of 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) is added to a sample of the vaginal discharge.
  4. Vaginal pH > 4.5: An elevated pH is indicative of BV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candidiasis: Diagnosed primarily by clinical presentation and microscopic identification of yeast cells or pseudo hyphae.

 

Option C. Cervicitis: Diagnosed based on clinical findings and specific laboratory tests for pathogens like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Option D. Trichomoniasis: Diagnosed by identifying the flagellated protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis on a wet mount microscopy or by specific antigen tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amsel criteria are specifically used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis, requiring the presence of at least three out of four specific clinical and laboratory findings.

questions.text: If the RNA sequence is CAAGGU, what is the sequence of the template strand? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACCTTG

 

Explanation:

 

The given RNA sequence is CAAGGU. To determine the template strand sequence -

  1. Direction of RNA Sequence: The RNA sequence is provided without directions, but typically the sequence is read from 5' to 3'. Thus, the sequence is 5'-CAAGGU-3'.
  2. Non-Template Strand (Coding Strand) of DNA: The non-template strand of DNA has the same sequence as the RNA transcript except for the replacement of uracil (U) with thymine (T). Therefore, the non-template strand would be 5'-CAAGGT-3'.
  3. Template Strand of DNA: The template strand of DNA is complementary to the non-template strand. Complementarity means adenine (A) pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) pairs with guanine (G). Therefore, the template strand, read in the 3' to 5' direction, would be:
    • C pairs with G
    • A pairs with T
    • A pairs with T
    • G pairs with C
    • G pairs with C
    • U (in RNA) pairs with A (in DNA, U replaced by T in RNA, so G pairs with C)

 

Therefore, the template strand is 3'-GTTAAC-5'. When we reverse the direction to match the 5' to 3' orientation given in the options, the sequence is ACCTTG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CAAGGT: This option is the sequence of the non-template (coding) strand of DNA, not the template strand.

 

Option B. GTTCCA: This option is not complementary to the RNA sequence.

 

Option D. TGGAAC: This option is incorrect as it does not match the complementary base pairing rules for the given RNA sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The template strand of DNA is complementary to the RNA sequence and the non-template strand, with the RNA sequence transcribed from the 5' to 3' direction of the non-template strand.

choices.text: Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume
Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure at the aortic valve
Workload has nothing to do with myocardial oxygen consumption
Increased pressure - Increase in preload more than afterload

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with dyspnea and chest pain. Which of the following proves that she has aortic stenosis rather than aortic regurgitation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume

 

In cases of aortic stenosis, the primary issue is the increased afterload due to the obstruction in the aortic valve, which forces the left ventricle to work harder to push blood against the increased resistance. This increased pressure work leads to higher myocardial oxygen consumption because the heart needs more energy to overcome the obstruction. The increase in pressure work (afterload) is significantly more in aortic stenosis than in aortic regurgitation, where volume overload (preload) is more prominent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure at the aortic valve: This statement is incorrect because aortic stenosis actually increases the pressure at the aortic valve due to the obstruction, not reduces it.

 

Option C. Workload has nothing to do with myocardial oxygen consumption: This is incorrect. Myocardial oxygen consumption is directly related to the workload of the heart. Increased workload, especially due to pressure overload in conditions like aortic stenosis, results in higher oxygen consumption.

 

Option D. Increased pressure - Increase in preload more than afterload: This is incorrect because in aortic stenosis, the afterload (pressure) is more significantly increased than the preload. Preload (end-diastolic volume) is typically increased in conditions like aortic regurgitation, not aortic stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic stenosis is characterized by increased pressure work (afterload) leading to higher myocardial oxygen consumption, distinguishing it from aortic regurgitation, which is associated with volume overload (preload).

questions.text:
Identify the findings in freshwater drowning? (INICET Nov 2020)

  1. Hemodilution

  2. Hypokalemia

  3. Hyponatremia

  4. Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1, 3, 4

 

Rather than hypokalemia, there is an increase in potassium levels due to the release of intracellular potassium from swollen red blood cells. Hypokalemia is not typically a finding in freshwater drowning.

 

1. Haemodilution: Due to the excessive absorption of water through the alveolar-capillary membrane, the blood becomes diluted.

 

3. Hyponatremia: Haemodilution leads to a decrease in the concentration of sodium in the blood.

 

4. Arrhythmia: Electrolyte abnormalities caused by the haemodilution and resultant imbalance can lead to cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of freshwater drowning, we see

 

  • Hemodilution – Due to excessive fluid absorption

  • Hyponatremia – Due to hemodilution

  • Arrythmia – Due to electrolyte abnormalities

  • Hyperkalemia -Due to release of intracellular potassium from swollen RBCs

questions.text: Which of the following is least useful in the management of a patient with Thalamic Dejerine syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ibuprofen

 

Explanation:

 

Thalamic Dejerine syndrome, also known as Dejerine-Roussy syndrome, is characterized by chronic, intense pain on the contralateral side of the body following a thalamic stroke. The pain is often resistant to typical analgesics and requires specific management with medications that target neuropathic pain.

 

Medications useful in managing Thalamic Dejerine syndrome include:

 

  • Amitriptyline: A tricyclic antidepressant effective in treating neuropathic pain.
  • Gabapentin: An anticonvulsant used to manage neuropathic pain.
  • Carbamazepine: An anticonvulsant also used for neuropathic pain management.

 

Ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is not effective for neuropathic pain and therefore is the least useful in managing Thalamic Dejerine syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A, B & C are effective for neuropathic pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ibuprofen is least useful for managing Thalamic Dejerine syndrome, which requires medications that target neuropathic pain.
